importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The game took place on October 17, 2025, and marked a significant moment in NFL history as it featured two of the league's oldest active quarterbacks, Joe Flacco and Aaron Rodgers, demonstrating that veteran players can still perform at a high level in modern football.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The article was updated at 6:11 AM EDT on October 17, 2025, indicating recent developments in the game's aftermath, including analysis of performance and commentary from coaches and players.

keyTakeAways: Joe Flacco, 40 years old, outperformed Aaron Rodgers, 41 years old, in a high-scoring game between the Cincinnati Bengals and Pittsburgh Steelers, helping the Bengals win 33-31.
The game, dubbed the 'Icy Hot Bowl' by Steelers teammate Cameron Heyward, highlighted the continued relevance of veteran quarterbacks in the NFL despite the league's youth trend.

Flacco threw for 342 yards and three touchdowns, including one to Ja’Marr Chase, one to Tee Higgins, and one to Noah Fant, and orchestrated a critical two-minute drive that led to a winning field goal.
The Bengals' offense showed strong cohesion, with Chase and Higgins each having standout performances, and Chase Brown rushing for over 100 yards for the first time this season.

Aaron Rodgers had a productive performance, throwing four touchdowns and two interceptions, and moved into fifth place on the NFL all-time career passing yards list, passing Ben Roethlisberger with 116 yards.
The Steelers fell to 4-2 but remain atop the AFC North, setting up a pivotal matchup against the Green Bay Packers in Week 8.
Flacco's performance marked his first win in Cincinnati after being acquired following injuries to Joe Burrow and Jake Browning, proving his value as a reliable backup quarterback.

namedEntities.name: Joe Flacco
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former NFL quarterback, currently playing for the Cincinnati Bengals
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Flacco was the winning quarterback in a crucial game against the Steelers, showing elite performance at age 40, including 342 yards and three touchdowns.

namedEntities.name: Aaron Rodgers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former NFL quarterback, currently playing for the Pittsburgh Steelers
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Rodgers played a key role in the game, throwing four touchdowns and passing Ben Roethlisberger to move into fifth place on NFL all-time career passing yards list.

namedEntities.name: Cincinnati Bengals
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An NFL team based in Cincinnati, Ohio
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Bengals hosted the Steelers and won 33-31, marking a pivotal win in their season after a previous loss and the absence of starting quarterback Joe Burrow.

namedEntities.name: Pittsburgh Steelers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An NFL team based in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Steelers were the visiting team who lost in a dramatic, high-scoring game, falling to 4-2 and remaining in contention in the AFC North.

namedEntities.name: Cameron Heyward
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Steelers defensive player and teammate of Aaron Rodgers
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Heyward coined the nickname 'Icy Hot Bowl' for the game, highlighting the contrast between the cold weather and intense competition.

namedEntities.name: Joe Burrow
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former NFL quarterback, previously with the Cincinnati Bengals
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His long-term injury led to the trade of Joe Flacco to the Bengals, creating the need for a reliable backup quarterback.

namedEntities.name: Jake Browning
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Backup quarterback for the Cincinnati Bengals
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Browning's poor debut performance led to Flacco being brought in as a starter.

namedEntities.name: Ja’Marr Chase
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Wide receiver for the Cincinnati Bengals
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Caught a touchdown pass from Flacco and had a strong performance with 16 catches for 161 yards.

namedEntities.name: Tee Higgins
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Wide receiver for the Cincinnati Bengals
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Caught a touchdown pass from Flacco and had a season-high six catches for 96 yards.

namedEntities.name: Noah Fant
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Wide receiver for the Cincinnati Bengals
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Caught a touchdown pass from Flacco, contributing to the Bengals’ three-touchdown output.

namedEntities.name: Chase Brown
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Running back for the Cincinnati Bengals
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Ran for over 100 yards for the first time this season, showing improved performance in the running game.

namedEntities.name: Pat Freiermuth
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Tight end for the Pittsburgh Steelers
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Caught a 68-yard touchdown pass from Rodgers in the final minutes, helping the Steelers tie the game at 31-31.

namedEntities.name: Evan McPherson
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Converted a 36-yard field goal in the final minutes to give the Bengals a two-point lead.

namedEntities.name: Zac Taylor
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Head coach of the Cincinnati Bengals
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Praised Flacco’s composure and leadership during the final drive, calling his performance 'outstanding.'

namedEntities.name: Brett Favre
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former NFL quarterback, former leader in career passing yards
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Rodgers is still over 7,000 yards behind Favre in career passing yards, highlighting the gap between Rodgers and the all-time leader.

namedEntities.name: Ben Roethlisberger
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former Pittsburgh Steelers quarterback, all-time leading passer in franchise history
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Rodgers passed Roethlisberger for fifth place on the NFL career passing yards list during the game.

namedEntities.name: Super Bowl XLVII
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A previous championship game in NFL history
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Flacco's previous championship win in Super Bowl XLVII is referenced as a point of pride and legacy in his career.

namedEntities.name: Week 8
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The upcoming NFL week scheduled for a game between the Steelers and Green Bay Packers
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Steelers' loss in this game sets up a critical matchup in Week 8 against the Packers, a team Rodgers previously played for.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In a high-energy Thursday Night Football clash dubbed the 'Icy Hot Bowl' by Steelers teammate Cameron Heyward, 40-year-old Joe Flacco outperformed 41-year-old Aaron Rodgers in a dramatic 33-31 victory for the Cincinnati Bengals over the Pittsburgh Steelers. Flacco, acquired to replace injured starters Joe Burrow and Jake Browning, threw for 342 yards and three touchdowns, including key plays to Ja’Marr Chase, Tee Higgins, and Noah Fant, and orchestrated a crucial two-minute drive culminating in a winning field goal by Evan McPherson. The Steelers, led by Rodgers who passed Ben Roethlisberger to move into fifth place on the NFL all-time passing yards list, had briefly led with a 68-yard touchdown to Pat Freiermuth, but ultimately couldn’t recover. Despite the loss, the game highlighted the enduring relevance of veteran quarterbacks in the NFL, with both Flacco and Rodgers delivering standout performances in a game that kept fans engaged and underscored the resilience of aging athletes in modern football. The Bengals improved to 3-4 on the season, while the Steelers fell to 4-2 and remain atop the AFC North, preparing for a pivotal showdown against the Green Bay Packers in Week 8.
title: Joe Flacco outduels Aaron Rodgers in battle of elder statesmen as Bengals stun Steelers in ‘Icy Hot Bowl’
